column1: I enjoyed participating in the classroom activity.
column2: The classroom activity was interesting and held my attention.
column3: I felt motivated to participate actively in my group.
column4: The activity helped me better understand the concepts of distributed architectures.
column5: The practical exercise was more useful than just reviewing theory.
column6: I would like this type of activity to be included regularly throughout the semester.
column7: I can apply what I learned in this activity in academic or professional projects.
column8: Designing the architecture helped me connect theory with real-world use cases.
column9: The instructions were clear and easy to follow.
column10: The support material (cheat sheet, guide) was useful for completing the activity.
column11: The time we allotted for the classroom activity was adequate.
column12: The group work helped me learn from my classmates.
column13: The exchange of ideas between teams was valuable for enriching my proposal.
column14: What did you like most about the classroom activity?
column15: What would you improve for future editions?

column14: Learning how to connect/link more AWS services.
The simplicity of the teaching, since it didn’t mix content and was easy to understand.
The explanation of the classroom activity’s theory.
Sharing ideas with my partner to find an optimal solution.
column15: Explaining a case before doing the exercise.

column14: I found the practical exercise very interesting because each group had a different case.
column15: Nothing; everything seemed fine to me.

column14: I liked learning about AWS services.
column15: I don’t think focusing on the tools is the best strategy. I think the problem should be presented first, and then the student should look for a way to solve it. Not give a list and try to fit into it, because that doesn’t seem realistic to me.

column14: They explained three important concepts in a simple and clear way.
Being able to practice building our architecture.
column15: Nothing; I liked how dynamic and practical it was.

column14: The explanation of the examples for each architecture.
I didn’t know this type of architecture; I had a general idea, but not a full grasp of these concepts.
column15: More features or somewhat more rigorous methodologies (more detailed examples done by the students).

column14: The practical part of thinking/creating an architecture having certain (given) services as a base.
column15: More activities, maybe hands-on practice directly in AWS.
Using the architecture directly in AWS.

column14: How real-life use was explained, with companies like 3M as examples.
column15: A bit more time, or restructure how it is allocated/distributed.

column14: It made us think about how to improve a system based on the context we assumed.
column15: That the classroom activity not be only in pairs, but in groups of up to 4 students.

column14: The dynamism and practicing the theory we saw reinforces the knowledge acquired even more.
